data:
"You'll see...things will be better in Florida."

Packing us all into the old Ford and hitting the road was the plan of the day.  Running was always the way of dealing with things and this was a run for the gold.

"I'm gonna miss him.  He took care of us and now we're on our own.  But don't worry, I'll find another man who will love us."

She couldn't understand the concept of being worth something.  Men and women, in her mind anyway, each had their roles to play.  The men took care of the women, and in return the women did whatever they had to do.  She would start a business in Florida which would feed us all until she found the new Mr. Right.  It all meant nothing but a temporary belief in herself.  She could start a business but if she had to do it on her own, it would have to be temporary.  How could it be otherwise?

"Can we stop?  I have to go to the bathroom."

"Soon, dear, soon."

The long road flies by us as rain hits the hood of the old Ford.  What could we do but go along with this plan?  One day we'll grow up and do our own running.  One day we'll grow up and regress just like she has.

"Why do people die Mom?"

"They just do honey, they just do."

We finally stop and for a moment, I think of running away.  They won't miss me - I'm not worth anything to them anyway.  It's a circular thing.  I go to the bathroom and return to the car knowing that I have nowhere else to go.  An eleven year old goes where he's taken.

"You'll see, kids, it'll all work out in Florida."

Be inquisitive. Know what you don't know.
"You'll see...things will be better in Florida."
"You'll see, kids, it'll all work out in Florida."
I think ‚Äúthe future of awesome‚Äù really means ‚Äúnot quite awesome yet.‚Äù üòé
‚ÄúWhen one part of America hurts, we all hurt.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy do you go away? So that you can come back. So that you can see the place you came from with new eyes and extra colors. And the people there see you differently, too. Coming back to where you started is not the same as never leaving.‚Äù - Terry Pratchett
This faux caf√© cubano I‚Äôm drinking evokes fond memories of Miami, thank you.

The long road flies by us as rain hits the hood of the old Ford.  What could we do but go along with this plan?  One day we'll grow up and do our own running.  One day we'll grow up and regress just like she has.
Some stops in the journey border on unbearable but a new world is always just around the corner and when we‚Äôre lucky, it‚Äôs a better place.

From Colorado to Delaware to Florida to Illinois to Michigan. All the stops in one‚Äôs journey define who they are and going back to where one started is just a visit to another new, though familiar place.
Packing us all into the old Ford and hitting the road was the plan of the day.  Running was always the way of dealing with things and this was a run for the gold.

It was an old step van and the passenger seat wasn‚Äôt anchored. As my father drove, the seat slid forward then back then forward again. What a ride! I‚Äôm [guessing](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#shatters) I was about 10 or 11-years-old then based on the fact that Tony was with us in the van. He was a guy my father helped to immigrate from Cuba (in 1959?). We were on the way to [the bay](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#the%20bay).

We finally stop and for a moment, I think of running away.  They won't miss me - I'm not worth anything to them anyway.  It's a circular thing.  I go to the bathroom and return to the car knowing that I have nowhere else to go.  An eleven year old goes where he's taken.

It used to be that crossroads were simple intersections. Continue down the road or turn on to the other. Dealing with that simple intersection was at least doable and if the wrong decision was made, getting back to the crossroad was always possible. It was never exactly like that though it seemed to be. A little hope always went a long way.

Decades ago, I was one of the giggling twins standing and jumping up and down on the passenger seat next to our mother who was driving the little Nash Rambler. I think we were about 3 years old at the time and this is the earliest memory I‚Äôve managed to retain over the years.
getting lost is the real deal

I can remember walking around the old neighborhood wondering what water temperature would be best for washing my hair. I also thought about whether or not I would ever have it cut again. It had grown quite long while I was in school and coming back to the neighborhood after almost four years was awkward for me to say the least. I needed to find a job quick. Living in that old house again on Royal Palm Avenue with my mother wasn't an option. I wouldn't have been able to handle that for very long and as it turned out, I didn't have to. Nor did I cut my hair.

helplessly hoping was the song i was trying to remember that last night we stepped into reality knowing neil would carry the show to the next level of magic for the new year the new decade the new millennium the new medium and david was just happy to have survived and the spirit of the old days was the spirit of the new ways to say the same thing over and over and over again
"I'm gonna miss him.  He took care of us and now we're on our own.  But don't worry, I'll find another man who will love us."
Coming to, coasting through spaces between trees, he recovers unscathed, living to tell the story 50 years later.

not disappointed but who appointed me anyway to speak for a mass of people i don‚Äôt really know and the mass of hopes left to grow stale in the moonlight last night last sight he was running away with a link in his hand a link that could make a stand as crowds cheer in a dirty alley where hookers and hawkers peddle their wares staring into dead darkness with nothing going on but the throng of songs embedded in our heads staying there reminding us of what we‚Äôve seen until we‚Äôre dead with nothing left to say but i wish it would last just one more day

She couldn't understand the concept of being worth something.  Men and women, in her mind anyway, each had their roles to play.  The men took care of the women, and in return the women did whatever they had to do.  She would start a business in Florida which would feed us all until she found the new Mr. Right.  It all meant nothing but a temporary belief in herself.  She could start a business but if she had to do it on her own, it would have to be temporary.  How could it be otherwise?
(of a person or their behavior) primarily concerned with making money at the expense of ethics: _she's nothing but a mercenary little gold digger._

She told us there were liberals living next door as if we would think that was bad thing. ‚ÄúThey didn't like the sign in our yard.‚Äù Funny how easy it is to be so full of yourself that you think others would have to agree with you. You're on the right side of history after all. How could anyone not agree?
I was supposed to be a pharmacist. If being a doctor or a lawyer didn't appeal to me, I could at least consider being a pharmacist. That was all she asked. At least, consider it.
- There are things I want to understand but never will and there are things I understand no one else would ever want to.
An odd example as if it was written by an angry misogynistic guy or something. I‚Äôm just saying...

In my life and especially on the web, I have this thing about keeping the personal and commercial stuff separate. Like anyone, I have a business side. No one can survive without taking care of business.

it dawns on me that the caps were killed by a new medium that understood the lack of structure in peoples‚Äô minds helplessly hoping for something new helplessly lost in the din of the same old thing being said over and over and over again in new and different ways
a lottery window in the middle of poverty seems right somehow i forgot what it was like to be cold and hungry luck like ours is hard to come by days turning into night unfulfilled

My good friend Anne once ended a blog post with the question, ‚ÄúAnything you‚Äôve learned from life so far you‚Äôd care to pass along?‚Äù That was a long time ago but I‚Äôve finally gathered just a few answers:
because of it being that way.
you are me before the storm
"They just do honey, they just do."
I got a thing to say

we buy we try we fly to new places which look just like where we came from and offer no new answers click fast don‚Äôt stay don‚Äôt read don‚Äôt play just keep moving on to the next pointless wealth of information that we don‚Äôt really care about anyway we‚Äôre so cool for fools we‚Äôre so empty that we‚Äôre always longing to be full

helplessly hoping to free myself of this load helplessly grabbing for the next winning number in the stream of addiction the next spinning thunder in the noise of the same old thing over and over and over again
a dip in cold water after days in the rough looking directly at the sun new days new ways to think about the same old things bugging me i wait for the chill to take over again and again
getting lost on the web is all i live for now getting lost on the web is my fate getting lost on the web is a sign it‚Äôs too late
I want to deal with what‚Äôs possible, not wallow is what‚Äôs already taken place and left its ugly mark.

So this lady‚Äôs at our house a few weeks before Christmas and we‚Äôre talking. The conversation turns to her partner needing some rare medication that‚Äôs easier to get in Mexico. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not sure about going to Mexico,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúOkay, I know it‚Äôs a Trump thing and all but those caravan people are there.‚Äù Whoa!
and I know how to make one!
*   There‚Äôs no shortage of crazy in the world.

that blues song in my head ever changing ocean breeze and clarity objects of my hunger as somewhere on river street a mime mesmerizes strangers looking for the void they misplaced looks on their faces telling life stories
"Can we stop?  I have to go to the bathroom."
- I don't know how many times I've tried to start this thing.
So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.
whining is so easy but it really don‚Äôt please me let me out now before i explode

I‚Äôm convinced the thought that fills my mind most of the time is just a complex of [reactions](reactions.md) to the strange world I‚Äôm living in. Creative [urges](urges-1.md) struggle to redirect my mind to what I don‚Äôt see, to what might be.

so i speak and my soul leaks onto the tired pavement where we all met that night to share our inner thoughts with all the strangers we‚Äôve never seen except in dreams of schemes of using them for our own selfish gain replacing the pain of true emptiness
The thing about repressed memories is that they never really go away.
I‚Äôm trying to find my way back to what I was thinking just a moment ago.
